manuscript.title: ʿUmdetu'l-Ḥuffāẓ fî Tefsîri Eşrefi'l-Elfāẓ (عمدة الحفاظ في تفسير أشرف الألفاظ)
manuscript.author: Aḥmad b. Yūsuf al-Ḥalabī, known as Samīn al-Ḥalabī (d. 756/1355)

paper_decoration.summary: The first two pages (ff. 1b–2a) bear gold-worked (zerkâri) borders and gold-worked margins. The colophon section (hâtime) is similarly zerkâri-decorated. All pages carry gold cetvels (ruling lines). The decoration programme concentrates luxury treatment on the opening leaves and at the terminal colophon — a characteristic pattern of later Ottoman tafsīr manuscripts. The full extent of the margin zerkâri is not confirmable from the digitized portion alone (only 112 of approximately 952 pages are digitized), but the catalogue description by Ahmet Ali Balcı, a reliable recorder of this collection, explicitly documents 'ilk iki sayfa zerkâri-bordürlü, kenarları, hâtime zerkâri'.

key_indicators: Dated AH 1177 / CE 1763–64: late Ottoman period, consistent with continued luxury tafsīr production
Zerkâri-bordürlü on opening pages and hâtime: characteristic concentration at liminal zones of the codex
Gold cetvels throughout: standard late Ottoman framing system
Amasya Beyazıt collection context: manuscripts range from locally produced to Istanbul-made and later deposited in Amasya
cross_tradition_caveats: No colophon copying-place notation survives in the digitized portion; Istanbul versus provincial Amasya production cannot be resolved visually
The 18th-century date places this in a period of diffuse Ottoman luxury production — regional workshops were capable of equivalent programmes
Zerkâri limited to opening bifolio and hâtime (not throughout) may indicate a provincial or modest-budget commission rather than full court-level production

limitations: Colophon (hâtime zerkâri) not capturable — digitization covers only pages 1–112 of approximately 952 total pages
Margin zerkâri decoration not clearly distinguishable from plain aged margins at current resolution
p003 shows very worn cover with stamps — no decoration visible
Gold-worked border detail on opening pages is consistent with 'zerkâri-bordürlü' but fine pattern structure is not fully resolved at screenshot resolution

elements.description: Gold cetvels (frame lines) and geometric border patterns visible around both text blocks on the double-page opening. The gold frames are consistent with 'zerkâri-bordürlü' (gold-worked borders). A geometric pattern is discernible in the gutter between the two pages. Detailed gold-worked border motifs not fully resolved at current screenshot resolution.

elements.description: Multi-line cetvels (jadwal) in gold framing both text blocks. The ruling system is consistent with late Ottoman luxury production of religious texts.
elements.location: full text block on both pages

folio_analyses.notes: First text opening of a large Arabic lexicographic work (approximately 952 pages). Gold frame lines clearly present; fine zerkâri motif structure requires higher resolution or in-person examination for full characterisation.

elements.description: Gold cetvels with continued ruling lines framing the text block. No zerkâri or other margin decoration visible on this subsequent page, consistent with the 'ilk iki sayfa' (first two pages) scope of the decorative programme.

folio_analyses.notes: Subsequent page confirms that gold ruling continues throughout but zerkâri decoration is confined to the opening leaves.

bibliography.citation: Balcı, Ahmet Ali (cataloguer). YEK Portal catalogue record for Amasya Beyazıt Kütüphanesi MS 39 (YEK ID 385846). portal.yek.gov.tr.
bibliography.relevance: Primary source: catalogue entry documenting 'ilk iki sayfa zerkârî-bordürlü, kenarları, hâtime zerkârî'. Ahmet Ali Balcı is the principal cataloguer for the Amasya Beyazıt collection in YEK.

bibliography.citation: Samīn al-Ḥalabī, Aḥmad b. Yūsuf (d. 756/1355). ʿUmdat al-Ḥuffāẓ fī Tafsīr Ashraf al-Alfāẓ. Ed. Muḥammad Bāsil ʿUyūn al-Sūd. 4 vols. Beirut: Dār al-Kutub al-ʿIlmiyya, 1996.
bibliography.relevance: Critical edition of the primary text: a major Arabic Quranic lexicographic work. Understanding the text's madrasa-curriculum status explains the frequency of luxury manuscript production of this title.

bibliography.citation: Blair, Sheila S. 'Color and Gold: The Decorated Papers Used in Manuscripts in Later Islamic Times.' Muqarnas 17 (2000): 24–36.
bibliography.relevance: Key reference on decorated paper techniques including zerkâri, with comparative examples from Ottoman and Persian manuscripts. Essential for situating this manuscript's gold-worked opening pages within the broader tradition.

bibliography.citation: Tanındı, Zeren. 'Some Problems of Ottoman Manuscript Illumination.' Manuscripts of the Middle East 4 (1989): 54–59.
bibliography.relevance: Foundational study on Ottoman manuscript illumination, addressing the relationship between Istanbul court production and provincial copies, directly relevant to the attribution question for this Amasya manuscript.
bibliography.access_notes: Available in research libraries; open-access via Leiden University.

bibliography.citation: Tanındı, Zeren. 'Bibliophile Aghas (Eunuchs) at Topkapı Sarayı.' Muqarnas 21 (2004): 333–343.
bibliography.relevance: Addresses 18th-century Ottoman manuscript culture, patronage networks, and production centres outside the court proper — relevant to contextualising a dated 1763–64 luxury tafsīr copy from Amasya.

bibliography.citation: Gacek, Adam. Arabic Manuscripts: A Vademecum for Readers. Brill, Leiden/Boston, 2009.
bibliography.relevance: Standard reference for Arabic manuscript codicology and terminology, including colophon conventions (hâtime), ruling systems, and decoration programme vocabulary.

bibliography.citation: Déroche, François. The Abbasid Tradition: Qurʾāns of the 8th to the 10th Centuries AD. Nasser D. Khalili Collection of Islamic Art, Vol. I. London: The Nour Foundation / Azimuth Editions / Oxford University Press, 1992.
bibliography.relevance: Reference for Arabic manuscript decoration conventions and the typology of decorated openings; contextualises the treatment of the opening bifolio and colophon as privileged zones for luxury decoration.

bibliography.citation: Hillenbrand, Robert. Islamic Art and Architecture. London: Thames and Hudson, 1999.
bibliography.relevance: Broad survey providing context for Ottoman manuscript production within the wider Islamic arts tradition; includes discussion of the role of religious texts in generating luxury book arts.

suggested_collections.institution: YEK Portal — Amasya Beyazıt Kütüphanesi cluster
suggested_collections.reason: Six further manuscripts in the Amasya Beyazıt collection (shelfmarks 1, 50, 41, 53, 270, 1884) share the same zerkâri decoration family per cataloguer Ahmet Ali Balcı; comparative examination is recommended to establish the range of the programme.
Major repository of Ottoman religious manuscripts with luxury decoration programmes; comparable zerkâri-decorated tafsīr copies are likely held in multiple Süleymaniye collections.

provenance.notes: Held in the Amasya Beyazıt Kütüphanesi, a major provincial Ottoman library founded by Sultan Bayezid II in Amasya. The collection preserves manuscripts originally in Amasya's madrasas and institutions, associated with the city's long history as an Ottoman provincial centre and seat of şehzade education. No vakıf inscription is documented in the YEK catalogue entry for this manuscript. Catalogued by Ahmet Ali Balcı as part of the Amasya Beyazıt digitisation programme. IIIF identifier: 0000000381545. Digitised pages: approximately 112 of approximately 952 total pages (c. 12% coverage).
